greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Product of the primitive roots of prime(n).
comment: Except for n=2, we have a(n)=1 (mod prime(n)).
reference: C. F. Gauss, Disquisitiones Arithmeticae, Yale, 1965; see p. 52.
link: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..145
example: a(5)=672 because the primitive roots of 11 are {2,6,7,8}.
program: apply(p->a(0,p), primes(20)) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, May 15 2015
(Perl) use ntheory ":all"; sub list { my $n=shift; grep { znorder($_,$n) == $n-1 } 2..$n-1; } say vecprod(list($_)) for @{primes(nth_prime(20))}; # _Dana Jacobsen_, May 15 2015
xref: Cf. A060749 (primitive roots of prime(n)), A088144 (sum of primitive roots of prime(n)).
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Sep 27 2006
